facts.text: Civil Appeal No 32 of 1969 filed under section 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No 32 of 1969. Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated November 19, 1968 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court in Election Petition No. 14 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated November 19, 1968 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court in Election Petition No. 14 of 1968

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No 32 of 1969. Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated November 19, 1968 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court in Election Petition No. 14 of 1968. L. Sibal, Ram Sarup, S.C. Mahanta, K.C. Sharma and C. Talwar, for the appellant.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the election petition of the appellant

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal against the judgment and order dated 19 November, 1968 of the High Court of Punjab Haryana at Chandigarh dismissing the election petition of the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant contested the Assembly seat from Ellenabad Constituency in the District of Hissar in the mid-term election held in May, 1968

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytested the Assembly seat from Ellenabad Constituency in the District of Hissar in the mid- term election held in May, 1968.

facts.text: Appellant challenged the election of Lalchand, the first respondent

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the election of Lalchand, the first respondent. The other defeated candidate in the election was the second respondent Prithvi Raj.

facts.text: Votes: Appellant obtained 15,485 votes; Lalchand secured 20,816 votes; Prithvi Raj obtained 5,726 votes

anchor.surface_text: The other defeated candidate in the election was the second respondent Prithvi Raj. The appellant obtained 15,485 votes. The successful candidate Lalchand secured 20,816 votes and Prithvi Raj obtained 5,726 votes.

facts.text: Polling was on 14 May, 1968; results announced on 16 May, 1968

anchor.surface_text: The polling was on 14 May, 1968. The results were announced on 16 May, 1968.

facts.text: Appellant alleged poster Exhibit P.W. 1/1 was against personal character constituting corrupt practice under section 123(4) RPA

anchor.surface_text: First, that the poster being Exhibit P.W. 1/1 was against the personal character of the appellant and therefore companystituted a companyrupt practice within the meaning of sub-section  4  of section 123 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Sat Guru Jagjit Singh issued farman on or about 20 April, 1968 directing followers to oppose appellant, son of Choudhury Devi Lal, enemy of Namdhari Guru

anchor.surface_text: Counsel on behalf of the appellant pressed allegations companained in sub-paragraphs  b  and  d  of paragraph 10 of the petition which were to the effect that Sat Guru Jagjit Singh issued a farman on or about 20 April, 1968 to the effect that it was the Gurus desire that all followers should oppose the appellant who. was the son of Choudhury Devi Lal an enemy of Namdhari Guru.

facts.text: Meeting of Namdhari followers at Sant Nagar on 21 April, 1968 where Sat Guru Jagjit Singh made speech against appellant

anchor.surface_text: In sub-paragraph  d  of paragraph 10 of the petition it was alleged that on 21 April, 1968 the followers of Namdhari sect were called to Sant Nagar where, a big Dewan of Namdharis was companyvened and Sat Guru Jagjit Singh made a speech there that he had taken a vow to defeat the appellant because he was the son of Choudhury Devi Lal whose family was an avowed enemy of Namdhari sect

facts.text: Respondent Lalchand denied the farman and the meeting

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Lalchand denied that there was any meeting and further denied that there was any farman.

facts.text: Appellant adduced no documentary evidence for farman allegations, relied on oral evidence of PW 29 Ram Dayal and PW 30 Parma Nand Sharma

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, it may be stated,, did number adduce any documentary evidence in support of the allegations. The appellants entire case was based on oral evidence. The appellant relied on the oral testimony of P.W. 29 and P.W.

facts.text: Ram Dayal (PW 29) was former Punjab MLA, resigned Congress, contested against Choudhury Devi Lal in 1957 and won, unseated by Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: P.W. 29 Ram Dayal was formerly a member of the Punjab Legislative Assembly. Ram Dayal was formerly a member of the Congress Committee. He resigned from the Congress and companytested the seat as an independent candidate against Choudhury Devi Lal and won the election in the year 1957. An election petition was filed by Choudhury Devi Lal against the witness Ram Dayal. Ram Dayal was eventually unseated as a result of the decision of this Court.

facts.text: Ram Dayal helped respondent Lalchand in 1967 election and mid-term 1968 election

anchor.surface_text: The witness Ram Dayal helped the respondent Lalchand in the election of 1967 and also. in the mid-term election in the month of May, 1968.

facts.text: Court rejected oral evidence of PW 29 and PW 30 regarding farman and meeting on 21 April 1968

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the oral evidence that there was any meeting on 21 April, 1968 as alleged by the appellant and that Sat Guru Jagjit Singh spoke at the meeting, to cast votes in favour of respondent Lalchand under threat of divine displeasure and spiritual censure.

facts.text: Appellant alleged Lalchand gave Rs. 20,000 cash to Prithvi Raj to contest election, corrupt practice u/s 123(1) RPA

anchor.surface_text: Counsel on behalf of the appellant companytended that respondent Lalchand was guilty of offences under section 123 1  of the Act by having given Rs. 20,000/- in cash to respondent Prithvi Raj to companytest the election.

facts.text: Kumhar meeting on 30 March 1968 decided to field Prithvi Raj; Bawa Bir Singh paid Rs.20,000 to Prithvi Raj in presence of Lalchand (PW11,12,13)

anchor.surface_text: Kanshi Ram, P.W. 11 said that he was Kumhar and there was a meeting of the Kumhars on 30 March, 1968. It was decided that a Kumhar should be made a member of the Legislative Assembly. He also said that the Kumhars decided at the said meeting to put up respondent Prithvi Raj as a candidate. Kanshi Rams further evidence was that Bawa Bit Singh paid Rs. 20,000/- to Prithvi Raj for election expenses. Kanshi Ram said that the payment was in the presence of respondent Lalchand.

facts.text: No evidence of bribery by Lalchand or with his consent to induce Prithvi Raj to contest

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is number evidence to hold that any gift was made by the candidate or his agent or by any other person with the companysent of the candidate, namely, the respondent Lalchand. Secondly, there is numberevidence that gratification was made with the object of inducing the respondent Prithvi Raj to stand or number to stand as a candidate.

facts.text: Poster Exhibit P.W. 1/1 printed at Kwality Art Printers, 10,000 copies, on asking of Lalchand identified by Muni Lal Azad and Jai Gopal Verma

anchor.surface_text: W. 35, Lachhman Das was the Manager, Kwality Art Printers. He spoke of a poster which was printed in his Press. He identified the Exhibit P.W. 1/1 as a companyy of the poster which was printed in his Press. He said that Exhibit W. 34/2 was a manuscript of Exhibit P.W. 1/1. He further said that the pamphlet was printed on the asking of Lalchand who was identified by the witnesses Muni Lal Azad and Jai Gopal Verma. ... The further evidence was that 10,000 companypies of the poster were printed in the said Press.

facts.text: Copy of poster sent by Kwality Art Printers to Chief Electoral Officer received on 2 May 1968

anchor.surface_text: He sent a companyy of the poster to. the Chief Electoral Officer. The letter to the Chief Electoral Officer Exhibit P.W. 34/1 was in a sealed companyer. It was opened in this Court. It was proved by Muni Lal Jain, Accountant in the office of the Chief Electoral Officer. He proved that Exhibit P.W. 34/1 was the letter received from Kwality Art Printers on 2 May, 1968.

facts.text: Poster Exhibit P.W. 1/1 contained false statements about appellant indulging in smuggling and being obnoxious person

anchor.surface_text: The appeal which was published and distributed is Exhibit P.W. 34/2 which is the same as Exhibit P.W. 1/1. This appeal leaves number room for doubt that there were allegations against the personal character and companyduct of the appellant Om Prakash who was described as having been indulging in smuggling. In the said appeal, it was further said that the appellant was an obnoxious person.

facts.text: Evidence established publication of poster by Lalchand, relating to personal character of appellant, false and prejudicial to election prospects

anchor.surface_text: The evidence in the present case established beyond any measure of doubt first that Exhibit P.W. 1/1 which is the same as Exhibit P.W. 34/2 was published, secondly, that Lalchand got the same printed and published, thirdly, that the statement was in relation to the personal character and companyduct of the appellant, fourthly, the statement is false and fifthly, the same was calculated to prejudice the prospects of the appellants election.

facts.text: Court held Lalchand guilty of corrupt practice under section 123(4) RPA, appeal accepted

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we are of opinion that the appeal is to be accepted on the ground that respondent Lalchand is guilty of companyrupt practice under section 123 4  of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant is Om Prakash, son of Ch. Devi Lal

anchor.surface_text: the personal character and companyduct of the appellant Om Prakash who was described as having been indulging in smuggling.

facts.text: Diary entry Exhibit P.W. 24/2 dated 21 April 1968 mentions Sat Guru at Sant Nagar appealing to vote for Ch. Lalchand

anchor.surface_text: The appellant relied on the dairy entry of Gurbhajan Singh being Exhibit P.W. 24/2 beating the date 21 April 1968 in support of the companytention that there was intrinsic evidence in the dairy entry, that there was a meeting on 21 April, 1968 where Sat Guru Jagjit Singh spoke, and the said entry is in the following terms -- Asa Di war was recited at Sh. Jiwan Nagar. ... and made an appeal to the audience to cast their votes in favour of Ch. Lalchand independent candidate of Ellenabad Constituency and return him as successful candidate.

arguments.claim: Four elements of section 123(4) satisfied: publication by Lalchand, false statement re personal character, prejudicial

arguments.claim: PW29 Ram Dayal unreliable witness due to past enmity with Devi Lal family and support to Lalchand

anchor.surface_text: P.W. 29 Ram Dayal was formerly a member of the Punjab Legislative Assembly... unseated... The witness Ram Dayal helped the respondent Lalchand in the election of 1967 and also. in the mid-term election... It is indeed strange and significant that Ram Dayal who. supported respondent Lalchand... came and gave evidence in favour of the appellant... extremely unsafe...

arguments.claim: PW30 Parma Nand Sharma unreliable, proclaimed truthfulness suspiciously

anchor.surface_text: W. 30 Parma Nand Sharma... In cross-examination the witness Parma Nand Sharma said that he came to give evidence in favour of the Congress because he was summoned... It is obvious that when one speaks truth one does not proclaim it... wanted to sound truthful...

arguments.claim: Diary entry Exhibit P.W. 24/2 does not prove alleged utterances at meeting

anchor.surface_text: The appellant relied on the dairy entry... Exhibit P.W. 24/2... The diary entry is to the effect that the Sat Guru Jagjit Singh appeared before the Sant Nagar Assembly. The diary entry does not mention about any alleged utterance by Sat Guru Jagjit Singh at the said meeting.

arguments.claim: Pamphlets Exhibits P.W. 24/1 and P.W. 24/2 published after election, created deliberately

anchor.surface_text: Exhibits P.W. 24/1 and P.W. 24/2 are two pamphlets containing articles... Both the articles were published after the election had been held on 16 May, 1968. These articles suffer from the vice of coming into existence under deliberate motive.

arguments.claim: No evidence of gift with consent of Lalchand or object to induce Prithvi Raj under s.23(1)

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is no evidence to hold that any gift was made by the candidate or his agent or by any other person with the consent of the candidate... Secondly, there is no evidence that gratification was made with the object of inducing the respondent Prithvi Raj to stand or not to stand as a candidate.

arguments.claim: Evidence proves poster publication, printing by Lalchand, relates to character, false, prejudicial

anchor.surface_text: The evidence in the present case established beyond any measure of doubt first that Exhibit P.W. 1/1... was published, secondly, that Lalchand got the same printed and published, thirdly, that the statement was in relation to the personal character and conduct of the appellant, fourthly, the statement is false and fifthly, the same was calculated to prejudice the prospects of the appellants election.

arguments.claim: Lalchand guilty of corrupt practice u/s 123(4); election petition succeeds

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we are of opinion that the appeal is to be accepted on the ground that respondent Lalchand is guilty of corrupt practice under section 123 4  of the Act.

holdings.text: We are unable to accept the oral evidence that there was any meeting on 21 April, 1968 as alleged by the appellant and that Sat Guru Jagjit Singh spoke at the meeting, to cast votes in favour of respondent Lalchand under threat of divine displeasure and spiritual censure.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the oral evidence that there was any meeting on 21 April, 1968 as alleged by the appellant and that Sat Guru Jagjit Singh spoke at the meeting, to cast votes in favour of respondent Lalchand under threat of divine displeasure and spiritual censure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No documentary evidence; oral testimony of PW 29 Ram Dayal and PW 30 Parma Nand Sharma rejected for bias, lack of corroboration, and unreliability; diary entry does not support alleged threats or utterances.

holdings.text: In the present case, there is no evidence to hold that any gift was made by the candidate or his agent or by any other person with the consent of the candidate, namely, the respondent Lalchand. Secondly, there is no evidence that gratification was made with the object of inducing the respondent Prithvi Raj to stand or not to stand as a candidate.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is no evidence to hold that any gift was made by the candidate or his agent or by any other person with the consent of the candidate, namely, the respondent Lalchand. Secondly, there is noevidence that gratification was made with the object of inducing the respondent Prithvi Raj to stand or not to stand as a candidate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Oral evidence of PW 11, 12, 13 shows payment by Bawa Bir Singh in presence of Lalchand but no proof of consent by Lalchand or object of inducement under s.23(1); presence alone insufficient.

holdings.text: The evidence in the present case established beyond any measure of doubt first that Exhibit P.W. 1/1 which is the same as Exhibit P.W. 34/2 was published, secondly, that Lalchand got the same printed and published, thirdly, that the statement was in relation to the personal character and conduct of the appellant, fourthly, the statement is false and fifthly, the same was calculated to prejudice the prospects of the appellants election.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence in the present case established beyond any measure of doubt first that Exhibit P.W. 1/1 which is the same as Exhibit P.W. 34/2 was published, secondly, that Lalchand got the same printed and published, thirdly, that the statement was in relation to the personal character and conduct of the appellant, fourthly, the statement is false and fifthly, the same was calculated to prejudice the prospects of the appellants election.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unchallenged evidence from printer PW35 Lachhman Das, identifiers PW36,37, electoral office receipt on 2 May 1968, content alleging smuggling and obnoxious character falsely attacks personal character and conduct, prejudicial; all elements of s.123(4) proved.

holdings.text: For these reasons we are of opinion that the appeal is to be accepted on the ground that respondent Lalchand is guilty of corrupt practice under section 123(4) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we are of opinion that the appeal is to be accepted on the ground that respondent Lalchand is guilty of corrupt practice under section 123 4  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overwhelming evidence satisfies all requirements of s.123(4) corrupt practice regarding the poster Exhibit P.W.1/1.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is no evidence to hold that any gift was made by the candidate or his agent or by any other person with the consent of the candidate, namely, the respondent Lalchand. Secondly, there is noevidence that gratification was made with the object of inducing the respondent Prithvi Raj to stand or not to stand as a candidate.
For these reasons we are of opinion that the appeal is to be accepted on the ground that respondent Lalchand is guilty of companyrupt practice under section 123 4  of
